Sentence: Bank of America is distancing itself from its venture capital arm, BA Venture Partners, to concentrate on its middle-market private equity unit, BA Capital Investors.
BA Ventures said Wednesday that it would rename itself Scale Venture Partners as Bank of America repositions itself as a minority investor.
Bank of America Steps Back from Venture Arm
Alinta Ltd. has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank Ltd. in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout.
Australian Utility Giant Gets Buyout Offer From Managers

Bank of America has begun a push to raise a regulatory cap that bars any bank in the United States from an acquisition that would give it more than 10 percent of the nation’s total bank deposits, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.
The company has argued that United States banks are artificially small and vulnerable to foreign acquirers, the Journal said.
It said the bank last year won support for changing the policy in votes before the North Carolina Bankers Association and the New Hampshire Bankers Association.
Bank of America has also approached bankers in Massachusetts and other states to support potential legislation this spring in Congress, the Journal reported.
BofA Seeks a Lift on Deposit Caps
Big gains in equity investments buoyed Bank of America’s earnings in the fourth quarter.
Bank of America Profit Rises 47%
Bank of America and Wachovia, two of the nation’s largest banks, said Tuesday that their profits rose sharply in the fourth quarter compared with the same period a year earlier.
Results at both banks were helped by major acquisitions in 2006.
Bank of America, which bought the credit-card giant MBNA last year, said its net income rose 47 percent, to $5.26 billion, in the fourth quarter.
Wachovia, which picked up Golden West Financial, said its fourth-quarter profit increased 35 percent, to $2.3 billion.
Profit Jumps at BofA, Wachovia
Bank of America had argued that the law restricting a bank to no more than 10 percent of the nation’s deposits is “antiquated” and anticompetitive.
Big Bank Stops Effort to Change Law Limiting Growth

Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions.

Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to “back off” from those plans.
Bank of America Tones Down Deposit Cap Stance

Bank of America on Wednesday said its board of directors authorized the repurchase of up to 200 million additional common shares, and will allow management to spend $14 billion over the next 12 to 18 months to buy back stock.
The No.
2 U.S. bank said it has 63 million shares remaining under a 200 million share buyback program authorized last April.
Bank of America’s market capitalization is more than $200 billion.
Bank of America Board Greenlights Buyback

The opening of Time Warner Cable shares on the public market faces yet another delay after a federal judge on Wednesday blocked Adelphia Communications, the cable television company, from moving ahead with its $15 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

The judge granted a request by an 11-member bondholder group, which includes Lehman Brothers and Bank of America, to appeal the Jan. 3 order approving the reorganization plan which they say undervalues their claims.
Adelphia Ruling to Delay Time Warner Cable Offering

Bank of America and Countrywide Financial have held discussions about an “alliance” that could eventually lead to an acquisition of Countrywide by Bank of America, The Financial Times reported Friday afternoon, citing unnamed sources.
Such a deal would create the biggest mortgage lending group in the United States, joining Bank of America’s size and Countrywide’s significant lending business.
Analysts said a Countrywide buyout could cost BofA about $30 billion.
BofA and Countrywide Said to Discuss Alliance
Bank of America was fined $3 million by the NASD Monday to settle charges it failed to follow rules designed to stop money laundering in its handling of accounts held by a single family.

While the NASD did not identify the family, Reuters said that the accounts are identical to those held by Dallas billionaire Sam Wyly and his brother Charles, as described in an August 2006 report, “Tax Haven Abuses: The Enablers, the Tools and Secrecy,” by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
NASD Fines Bank of America $3 Million

Asked about recent reports that Bank of America was in talks that might lead to an acquisition of Countrywide, Bank of America Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said Wednesday his company would follow a mortgage strategy of “organic growth.” Speaking at a financial-services conference, he also said the odds were “pretty low” that his company would buy a large United States bank this year, Reuters reported.
BofA Chief Says Big U.S. Deal Is Unlikely
The U.S. buyout firm whose sale of Korea Exchange Bank was blocked by a corruption investigation, will collect $445 million in dividends from the bank.
Big Dividend for Lone Star
Lone Star Funds will recoup almost a third of its original investment in a move that drew divided reaction.
Lone Star Gets Big Dividend in Korea Deal

Thomas Weisel Partners, the technology-oriented investment bank that went public a year ago, said that its chief financial officer, Robert K. West, would leave the firm April 6 to “pursue other interests.” Announcing the move in a regulatory filing Tuesday, the firm did not say when or how it planned to fill the vacancy.
Mr. West is just the latest finance chief at a financial firm to try something new.
In the past two months or so, Bank of America, Citigroup and Charles Schwab each announced that their finance chief would be leaving the post.
Thomas Weisel C.F.O.
to Resign
Bank of America‘s investment banking arm has hired a former dealmaker from Sprint Nextel as its global head of telecom mergers and acquisitions.
Marc Montagner joins Banc of America Securities after serving as head of mergers and acquisitions at Sprint Nextel, formed through a $35 billion merger in 2005.
Before Sprint Nextel, he was an investment banker at Morgan Stanley.
Telecom Dealmaker Joins Bank of America
Bank of America said it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.
U.S. Inquiry on Bonds at Big Bank
Bank of America said Friday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.
BofA Cooperating in Bond Inquiry
The differing financial styles of Bank of America and MBNA come together, and, mostly, it works.
A Clash of Cultures, Averted
Bank of America is backing away from “Higher Standards” — at least in its new national advertising campaign.
Bank of America Tagline Has Run Its Course
When Bank of America announced its $35 billion acquisition of MBNA in summer 2005, many people questioned whether it would work.
MBNA, a stand-alone credit-card giant, took pride in its fast-paced and entrepreneurial spirit, its freewheeling spending and a secretive corporate culture that seemed more like a cult.
So far, Bank of America, the acquisition-hungry giant, has let that stand, though it was not easy.
A Clash of Cultures, Averted
Federal authorities exposed one of the most far-reaching insider trading schemes on Wall Street in decades.
13 Are Accused of Trading as Insiders
Scale Venture Partners is saying adios to Bank of America as it closes its second fund.

The former venture arm of Bank of America (BA Venture Partners) said Wednesday that because of high demand from outside investors to participate in the $400 million fund, the bank made a graceful exit from the fund.
Bank of America Bids Adieu to Venture Arm
The bank will pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies.
Bank of America Pays Settlement in Improper Trading Case

Bank of America has agreed to pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies and failed to prevent leaks of reports that were used for improper trading, federal regulators said Wednesday.

With the settlement, Bank of America becomes the last bank to settle an industrywide inquiry into possible conflicts of interest between analysts and bankers and ends a six-year investigation into the company’s misuse of its own analysts’ research.
Bank of America Pays Settlement in Improper Trading Case
The reversal was prompted by what the retailer said was “manufactured controversy” surrounding the proposal.
Wal-Mart Drops Bid to Operate Its Own Bank
The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday.

Mr. Lewis, 59, received $1.5 million in salary, $6.5 million in nonequity incentive plan compensation, and stock and option awards that were valued by the company at $14.6 million on the dates they were issued.
At Bank of America, $23 Million for Chief
A nutritional supplement company, NBTY, is up for sale, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources.
The company’s market capitalization is $3.3 billion based on Tuesday’s trading.
Bear Stearns and Bank of America are advising NBTY and first-round bids are expected in the next few weeks.
Vitamin Maker NBTY Said to Seek a Buyer
Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of the U.S. Trust Corporation, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year.
Bank in Merger to Lose Executive
The Bank of America said Tuesday that Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of U.S. Trust, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year.
Mr. Scaturro, 47, will step down from U.S. Trust before the transaction is completed, a Bank of America spokeswoman said, declining to comment on the reason for his departure.
Mr. Scaturro had been expected to become head of Bank of America’s private-banking business after it purchased U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab.
Bank of America to Lose Executive in U.S. Trust Deal
Lone Star Funds said it would divest itself of two of its South Korean holdings, fueling speculation it was planning to exit the country.
Equity Firm to Sell South Korean Units
The nation’s largest education lender agreed to be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms.
Negotiators Say Sallie Mae to Be Sold for $25 Billion

Despite continuing fallout from subprime loans and clouds over the U.S. economy, three banking giants are expected to report relatively strong first-quarter earnings this week, according to MarketWatch.

On tap are J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup, which ast week unveiled a restructuring plan that would eliminate about 17,000 jobs worldwide and save the company an estimated $1.7 billion this year.
Big Banks Are Set for Strong 1st-Quarter Earnings
Sallie Mae agreed late last night to be sold to J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms for $25 billion.
The deal, announced early Monday, would move the nation’s largest education lender, officially known as the SLM Corporation, into private control amid increasing turmoil for the company.
Sallie Mae Agrees to Be Sold for $25 Billion
The education lender will be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms.
Sallie Mae to Be Sold for $25 Billion
Merrill Lynch said Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $2.16 billion, lifted by record investment-banking fees and trading revenue.
Merrill’s chief executive, Stan O’Neal, called it a “terrific quarter” despite a sometimes volatile environment.
Including Merrill’s latest figures, Bloomberg News reported that first-quarter profit at the five biggest securities firms in the nation totaled $9.7 billion, an all-time high.
Separately, Bank of America said Thursday that first-quarter profit increased 5 percent to $5.26 billion, helped by growth in fee income.
Merrill, Bank of America Report Higher Profits
ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by Barclays of Britain in a $91 billion deal that would be the largest financial-services merger in history.

To fend off a rival group of bidders seeking to break up the 183-year-old bank, ABN Amro and Barclays struck a separate agreement Sunday to sell the LaSalle Bank of Chicago, a unit of ABN, to the Bank of America for more than $21 billion.
Barclays Agrees to Buy ABN Amro in $91 Billion Deal
The deal with Barclays reduces, but does not eliminate, the chance of another suitor coming in with a higher bid.
Rival Offer Could Derail ABN Merger
In a surprise facet of the deal, ABN Amro said that it had arranged to sell LaSalle Bank to Bank of America.
ABN Amro to Be Acquired for $91 Billion
LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
Two Giants Vie for Bank in Chicago
Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution.
But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize.
Now, LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for at least two banking titans: Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
Banking Giants Bring the Fight to Chicago
One possible suitor may be out of the battle over ABN Amro‘s LaSalle Bank, the Chicago institution that its Dutch parent agreed to sell to Bank of America for $21 billion.
MAF Deal Puts Wind in National City’s Chicago Sails
Bank of America asked a federal court to prevent the Dutch bank ABN Amro from selling its Chicago subsidiary, LaSalle Bank, to rival bidders.
Bank of America Files Suit Over Deal to Buy LaSalle
The consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland is said to have submitted a $24.5 billion offer for LaSalle Bank, contingent on its successful takeover of ABN Amro.
Bidding War for ABN Amro Division Intensifies

The Dutch bank ABN Amro, the subject of one of the largest takeover battles in history, said Monday it had rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its Lasalle Bank subisidiary from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland, finding it “did not constitute a superior proposal” to a previous bid from Bank of America.
Nevertheless, ABN said it would allow shareholders to vote on the competing bid and others, as required by last week’s ruling in an Amsterdam court.
ABN Amro Rejects $24.5 Billion Bid for Lasalle Bank
ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August.
News of Mr. Scott-Barrett’s departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain.
ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America.
That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.
ABN Amro’s Finance Chief to Step Down
Media deals may be all the rage these days, but some analysts are seeing fodder for potential takeovers in the software industry as well.

Kirk Materne and Daniel Cummins of Bank of America ran the numbers and found eight big software companies with low-enough stock values to make them attractive takeover candidates, even if the acquirer shelled out a 25 percent premium to the current price.
The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked “inevitable.”
Bargain Spotting in the Software Sector
The Bank of America filed an appeal with the Dutch Supreme Court on Tuesday over a ruling this month that froze the company’s $21 billion purchase of the LaSalle Bank from ABN Amro.

“We’re confident that the Dutch Supreme Court, when presented with all the facts, will overturn the decision” of the Amsterdam Superior Court, Scott Silvestri, a Bank of America spokesman, told The Associated Press.
BofA Appeals Dutch Ruling on LaSalle Sale
The Bank of America, which expects to complete its $3.3 billion purchase of Charles Schwab‘s U.S. Trust private banking arm this fall.
said Thursday that its private banking chief, Jane Magpiong, plans to leave the company.
Bank of America’s Private Banking Chief to Step Down
The Italian bank UniCredit agreed to buy Capitalia for $29.5 billion as consolidation in Europe’s banking industry gathers pace.
Deal to Create Europe’s 2nd-Biggest Bank
Five black current and former employees of Bank of America have filed a lawsuit that accuses the bank of racial discrimination by steering lucrative clients to their white counterparts.
The complaint, filed Thursday in the Federal District Court in Boston, contends that the bank discriminates against African-Americans in pay, promotions, training and support services.
Bank of America Faces Discrimination Suit

The Chinese government’s $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group appears to be a move to pounce on a strategy many foreign banks have adopted in China: buy into a company just before it begins its initial public offering.
That strategy has given many banks, like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, significant initial gains, at least on paper, on their early investments, The New York Times writes.
China Says Blackstone Deal Is All About Returns
Wall Street banks, private equity firms and hedge funds are increasingly trying to arrange and finance entertainment deals.
At Cannes This Year, the Bankers May Outnumber the Movie Stars
One day before announcing it would spend $6.8 billion to buy the retail brokerage A.G. Edwards, Wachovia talked about a different kind of green.
On Wednesday, the nation’s fourth-largest bank said it would build only environmentally friendly branches by the end of 2008, starting with eight it plans to open soon in southern California.
The move follows large “green” commitments recently announced by the nation’s largest banks, Citigroup and Bank of America.
Wachovia Hops on the Green Bandwagon

Bank of America said Friday that it promoted Thomas G. White to head of global markets and that Mark Werner, who became chief executive of its investment banking arm less than two years ago, is leaving the company “to pursue other opportunities.” Bloomberg News said three of Mr. Werner’s top executives are leaving with him.
Bank of America Names Global Markets Head

Bank of America, seeking to overturn a decision that halted its $21 billion acquisition of the LaSalle Bank, is expected to claim that a Dutch commercial court acted in a “shocking” and unlawful manner in freezing the transaction, The Financial Times reported, citing a copy of the appeal filing the newspaper obtained.
The sale of LaSalle has emerged as a key element in the larger takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro.
Bank of America Said to Appeal Ruling on LaSalle Deal

Bank of America has postponed plans to take ABN Amro to court, preferring to wait until the Dutch Supreme Court rules on the Dutch bank’s sale of LaSalle Bank, its American unit, a Bank of America spokesman said on Friday.
Bank of America Holds Off on ABN Amro Lawsuit
Bank of America will see if a new name, U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management, can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.
Retail Giant Will Remake Private Bank
The Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people.
Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.
Bank of America to Remake Its Private Bank

Barclays got a big boost in its takeover battle for ABN Amro when an adviser to the Dutch Supreme Court said that it should allow the Dutch Bank to sell its Chicago-based LaSalle unit to Bank of America.
Barclays Bid Gets Boost from Court Adviser

Bank of America has completed its $3.3 billion acquisition of U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab and on Monday made several appointments to its newly-created Private Wealth Management organization, which has nearly $265 billion in assets under management and more than $427 billion in total client assets.
BofA Completes $3.3 Billion Deal for U.S. Trust
The Bank of England raised its key rate by a quarter point to 5.75 percent, while the European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate at 4 percent.
Bank of England Raises Key Rate
ALCOA QUESTIONED ON ALCAN BID Alcoa said that United States antitrust regulators had asked for more information about its $27.8 billion hostile takeover bid for a Canadian competitor, Alcan.
Alcoa said it would comply with the request from the Department of Justice “as soon as possible,” without saying what details it would provide.
Alcoa reiterated that it intended to complete the takeover this year.
The offer expires Tuesday and can be extended.
Alcan has urged shareholders to reject Alcoa’s bid, saying it is too low.
(BLOOMBERG NEWS).
Today in Business
Massachusetts’ top securities regulator is investigating whether major banks, including Bank of America, Morgan Stanley and Citigroup improperly sold complex investment products to customers.
Massachusetts to Investigate Sale of Investment Products
A fight is brewing over the role played by Bank of America in Rio Tinto‘s $38.1 billion offer for Alcan, The Daily Telegraph reported Friday.
BofA is believed to have been part of the original funding consortium but withdrew last weekend leaving Rio’s advisers at Deutsche Bank to arrange last-minute financing.
Banks Fume Over BofA’s Role in Alcan Deal
A Dutch court overturned an earlier ruling that had barred ABN Amro from selling its American subsidiary as part of a takeover deal with Barclays.
Ruling by Dutch Court Aids Barclays Bid for ABN Amro
The Dutch Supreme Court overturned a ruling that had blocked ABN Amro from selling its United States subsidiary, LaSalle Bank in Chicago, to Bank of America.
Ruling Helps Barclays in ABN Bid
COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season gets into full swing, particularly for technology, financial and drug companies.

Reports will come from Charles Schwab and Mattel (Monday); Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Novartis, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Altria, AMR, Delta Air Lines, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Pfizer, Southwest Airlines and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, Continental Airlines, Dow Jones, First Data, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Motorola and Wyeth (Thursday); and Boston Scientific, Caterpillar and Citigroup (Friday).
Looking Ahead
Bank of America may be too patriotic for its own good.
While the bank does more business in the United States than any of its competitors, its returns are being eroded, Bloomberg News reported Monday.
Is Bank of America Staying Too Close to Home?

Bank of America reported second-quarter profit of $5.76 billion, up 5.2 percent from a year ago, as revenue from bank charges and credit-card fees helped offset higher borrowing costs and bad loans, Bloomberg News reported.
Revenue at Bank of America, the second-largest United States bank, rose 7.8 percent to $20 billion in the quarter.
Bank of America Says Profits Rose 5.2 Percent
Although several of the nation’s biggest banks reported some of their best results ever this week, investors are worried about tougher times ahead.
Big Banks Offer Assurances to Calm Investors’ Jitters
Bank of America said on Thursday it asked a Manhattan federal judge to dismiss its lawsuit against ABN Amro seeking to block the Dutch bank from trying to sell its LaSalle Bank unit to other buyers.
BofA Seeks Dismissal of ABN Lawsuit
Bank of America‘s alternatives arm has appointed a new director of hedge fund investments as it folds in its recent acquisition of U.S. Trust.
Bank of America Names Head of Hedge Funds
BNP Paribas suspended operations of three funds over concerns about the drying up of credit.
Big French Bank Suspends Funds
Stocks dropped sharply as soon as trading opened today after a French bank, BNP Paribas, suspended operations of three of its funds in the wake of turmoil in the American market for home loans.
Stocks Tumble as French Bank  Reacts to Home Loan Worries

Berkshire Hathaway, the investment firm run by Warren Buffett, bought stakes in Dow Jones and Bank of America and more than quadrupled its holdings of the health insurers UnitedHealth Group and WellPoint.
Buffett Takes Stakes in Dow Jones
The SLM Corporation, commonly known as Sallie Mae, said on Wednesday its shareholders had approved the $25 billion acquisition of the student lender by a group of private equity firms and banks.
The company in April accepted the cash leveraged buyout proposal, worth $60 per share, from J.C.
Flowers, Friedman Fleischer & Lowe, Bank of America and J.P. Morgan Chase.
SLM Shareholders Approve Buyout
Clouds persisted Wednesday over European credit markets, with some commercial banks still reluctant to lend to each other.
European Banks Still Wary on Lending
More banks have stepped forward and said they have availed themselves of the Federal Reserve’s discount-lending rate cut amid the credit market’s turmoil last week.

The four biggest banks in the United States — Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Wachovia — said that they each borrowed $500 million through the so-called discount window by taking out loans directly from the Fed.
Top U.S. Banks Draw Upon Fed Discount Window
Countrywide Home Loans may not be able to meet its promise to investors of repurchasing loans if necessary.
Assurances on Buybacks May Cost a Lender

Bank of America said Wednesday that it has agreed to invest $2 billion in troubled lender Countrywide Financial, buying preferred shares that carry an interest rate of 7.25 percent and can be converted into common stock at $18 each.
BofA Buys $2 Billion Stake in Countrywide
Bank of America Center, an architectural icon on downtown Houston’s skyline, has been sold to Dallas-based Novati Group and an affiliate of the General Electric Pension Trust.
Houston’s Bank of America Center Sold
While stocks leveled off after the Fed’s rate cut, the woes from the collapse of the subprime mortgage market continued to claim more victims.
Wall Street, Still a Little Wobbly, Steadies Itself
The European Central Bank said volatility appeared to be returning after a period of stability, and the O.E.C.D.
warned of “ominous” risks to the global economic outlook.
New Concerns in Europe About Credit Fallout
Citing new economic uncertainties, the bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 4 percent, shifting course from a month ago when it signaled it would raise the rate.
Cautious European Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
Shares of Countrywide Financial fell Thursday below the $18 price at which Bank of America may convert its $2 billion investment into common stock.
The drop erased the $700 million paper profit Bank of America made when it invested $2 billion in the nation’s biggest mortgage lender two weeks ago.
Countrywide Drops Below Bank of America’s Deal Price

Biovail, the Canadian drug maker that is suing nearly two dozen parties for allegedly conspiring to drive its stock price down, has agreed to drop its claim against Bank of America and one of its analysts, The New York Post reported Monday.
Biovail Is Said to Settle with BofA

Bank of America, the Credit Suisse Group and UBS announced yesterday that they would join five other banks as members of a private system that lets institutional investors trade unregistered securities.
3 Banks Join System for Trading Unregistered Securities
Bank of America, Credit Suisse and UBS announced Wednesday that they would join five other banks as members of a private system that lets institutional investors trade unregistered securities.
3 Banks Join Private Placement Market
Comings and goings in the banking indurstry.
People in the News

Bank of America sold 230 billion yen ($2 billion) of global bonds on Friday, joining a handful of major banks that have sought to raise cash in Japan’s stable credit markets, Reuters reported Friday citing unnamed sources.
Bank of America Turns to Japan for Bond Sale
It is not a good sign that the private equity giant Blackstone now expects to get debt funding only for deals less than $1 billion – a far cry from the mega-leveraged buyouts of recent years.
That was just one of the points a Bank of America research analyst, Michael Hecht, highlights in a report from a meeting with the buyout firm’s president Tony James.
Is BofA’s View on Blackstone Too Rosy?
The consortium that had agreed to buy Sallie Mae for $25 billion may scuttle the deal if it is unable to negotiate a lower price.
Deal to Buy Sallie Mae in Jeopardy
The Bank of America said Monday that it would lay off about 2,500 Illinois employees over the next two years as part of its planned $21 billion purchase of the LaSalle Bank, Chicago’s No.
2 financial institution.
BofA’s LaSalle Deal to Lead to Big Layoffs
A consortium that had agreed to buy the student lender Sallie Mae for $25 billion said Wednesday that it was unwilling to complete the deal at the current price.
Deal at Risk, Buyers Warn Sallie Mae
Bear Stearns is in serious talks to sell as much as 20 percent of the firm, with several individual investors, including Warren E. Buffett, expressing an interest.
Buffett Said to Consider Bear Stake
Bank of America and LaSalle Bank, Chicago’s No.
2 bank, will begin operating as one company Monday, and many LaSalle executives will only stick around through the transition, according to a memo sent to workers on Friday.
Bank of America Takes Over LaSalle
Bank of America’s new campaign aims to convince the wealthy that a mass-market institution with a blue-collar image can also manage money for millionaires.
A Bank for the Masses Reaches for the Elite

While many Wall Street firms have pruned staff in recent weeks, Bank of America has added professionals to its New York equity capital markets division, among them Henry Erbe, who will head its equity capital markets for financial institutions business.
Bank of America Bulks Up Equity Capital Division
J.P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America are expected to take a combined $3 billion in writedowns when they report quarterly earnings later this month, an analyst estimated.

The Financial Times said the losses, from leveraged loans and mortgage-related securities, would take to more than $20 billion the total writedowns at the world’s top banks because of the summer’s market turmoil.
Writedowns Expected at J.P. Morgan and BofA
The giant student lender is suing the firms that agreed to buy it, but are now trying to renegotiate the deal.
Sallie Mae Sues to Force a Buyout
As Washington officials react with almost contented silence to a weak dollar, European officials are grumbling because it makes American exports cheaper in world markets.
U.S.
Affects a Strong Silence on Its Weak Currency
Several of the world’s biggest banks are in talks to put up about $75 billion in backup financing that could be used to buy risky mortgage securities and other assets.
Banks May Pool Billions to Avert Securities Sell-Off
Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase plan to create a $75 billion to $100 billion fund to buy bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks to Start Fund to Protect Credit Market
Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are  creating a fund to buy bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks Create a Fund to Protect Credit Market

Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, working together at the behest of the Treasury Department, announced Monday that they are creating a large fund to serve as a buyer of bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks to Start Fund to Protect Credit Market

Industry observers seemed to cast a jaundiced eye yesterday over a plan unveiled by Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, with active encouragement from the Treasury Department, to keep the housing-related debt crisis from worsening.
Is Banks’ Funding Plan Just Spin?
The bank was hurt by a spike in consumer credit costs and the poor performance of an investment banking unit.
Earnings Fall 32% at Bank of America

Bank of America, the third large money-center bank to report earnings this week, said its net income fell 32 percent in the third quarter to $3.70 billion, a sharper drop than many analysts had been expecting.
The decline was less than the 57 percent plunge in profits at Citigroup.
But the results were far worse than the 2 percent rise in earnings posted by J.P. Morgan Chase.
Bank of America’s Profits Fall 32 Percent
New York investment bankers sometimes refer to Bank of America as a “wannabe” investment bank, because its securities arm lacks the heft of its larger Wall Street rivals.
On Thursday, Bank of America proved that its investment banking unit could mess things up just as well as the big guys.
Will BofA Retreat From Investment Banking?
The bank was badly hurt by a huge spike in consumer credit costs and the poor performance of its investment banking unit, which has clamored for Wall Street’s respect.
Earnings Fall 32 Percent at Bank of America
Bank of America said its head of structured products left the company on Friday, one day after it reported a 32 percent decline in third-quarter profits.
The executive, Chris Hentemann, was succeeded by George Ellison, who had been Bank of America’s head of global structured finance.
BofA’s Head of Structured Products Departs
Like its most of its peers, Bank of America had a rough third quarter.
Last week, it reported a 32 percent drop in net income, including a stunning 93 percent drop at its investment bank.
Tightening the Belt at Bank of America
The axe has fallen.
Bank of America said it will eliminate 3,000 jobs following its announcement last week of a huge drop in earnings for the third quarter.
Most of the layoffs will come from its investment banking unit.
BofA also said it was starting a strategic review of its investment banking business, raising the prospect of significant changes for the firm.
3,000 Layoffs Today.
More Tomorrow?
